docs.title: Welcome to Yalin's Notes
docs.text: Hi there! Welcome to my GitHub repository where I share my study notes on math, computer science, statistics, and coursework from Coursera classes. I'm excited to have you here!

docs.title: About Me
docs.text: I am a Ph.D. Candidate in the Department of Geospatial Information Sciences at the University of Texas at Dallas (德州大学达拉斯分校).

docs.title: Week1: Ancillary items to FPM¶
docs.text: • Video Reference

docs.title: Introduction to the NFIP and Floodplain Management¶
docs.text: The National Flood Insurance Program (NFIP) forms the foundation of floodplain management in the United States. Understanding its core components is essential for passing the CFM exam, which consists of 120 multiple-choice questions covering various aspects of floodplain management, with a particular focus on NFIP minimum requirements.

docs.title: The Three Major Parts of the NFIP¶
docs.text:
The NFIP is built on three fundamental pillars (often described as "three legs" or "three pillars"):

  1. Insurance

  2. Mapping

  3. Regulation

docs.title: 🏛️ Roles of Federal and Local Governments in the NFIP¶
docs.text:
Entity Role Federal Government Develops policies, practices, laws, and flood insurance programs Local Communities Enforce regulations via building permits and inspections Local Officials Building officials and floodplain managers enforce compliance in their jurisdictions
  • FEMA conducts Community Assistance Visits (CAV) to review local documentation.
  • Local enforcement affects discount rates for flood insurance through the Community Rating System (CRS).

docs.title: ⚖️ Minimum and Cumulative Requirements of the NFIP¶
docs.text:
• Minimum Requirements:

    These are the bare minimum standards needed to comply with the NFIP.

    Similar to building codes, these ensure structures are legal and safe but represent the lowest acceptable level of protection.

  • Cumulative Requirements:

    Requirements build upon one another over time—referred to as the "NFIP staircase."

    As communities develop and improve floodplain management, they add layers of regulations to provide better protection and benefits.

  • The more advanced the requirements, the better the flood protection and potential lower flood insurance premiums for residents.

    | Concept | Explanation | |---------|-------------| | Minimum Requirements | Least acceptable standards to comply with NFIP regulations; equivalent to "building to code" | | Cumulative Requirements | Additional layers of rules added over time, enhancing flood protection and insurance benefits |

docs.title: 📜 Legislative Cornerstones Influencing the NFIP¶
docs.text:
Year Act/Legislation Key Points 1899 Navigable Stream, River, and Harbors Act Requires congressional approval for work on navigable waters (e.g., bridges, piers) 1979 Flood Disaster Protection Act Created FEMA 1994 National Flood Insurance Reform Act Major reforms in flood insurance policies 2000 Disaster Mitigation Act Requires local mitigation strategies for emergency planning (floods, hurricanes, tornadoes) 2004 & 2012 National Flood Insurance Reform Acts Biggert-Waters Act (2012) introduced reforms including moving flood insurance to actuarial rates; subsequent reforms addressed funding and subsidy issues
  • The Biggert-Waters Act aimed to reduce government subsidies for flood insurance, leading to higher premiums aligning with actual risk.
  • These legislative acts illustrate a progression toward more sustainable flood risk management and financial responsibility.

docs.title: 💧 Forces of Water in Floodplain Management¶
docs.text:
Water forces affecting floodplain structures are divided into two main categories:

Force Type Description Examples Hydrodynamic Moving water forces Waves, rivers, streams, flash floods Hydrostatic Standing water pressure Water pressure on basement walls
  • Hydrostatic pressure is crucial in understanding basement flooding:
    • When basements fill with water, the immediate reaction is to pump it out.
    • Pumping out water too quickly creates pressure imbalance because groundwater outside the basement walls remains high.
    • This pressure can cause cracks and water infiltration.
    • Recommendation: Lower water levels slowly and in stages to allow equilibrium and reduce damage.

docs.title: Important Basement Flooding Concepts¶
docs.text:
• When basements fill with water, immediate pumping can create pressure imbalance
  • Pumping too quickly creates pressure differential with outside groundwater
  • Can cause foundation cracks and water infiltration
  • Recommendation: Lower water levels slowly and in stages to allow equilibrium

docs.title: Multiple Objective Management (MOM)¶
docs.text:
• Balances multiple community goals in floodplain management
  • Considers watershed-wide impacts
  • Examines environmental resources
  • Balances losses vs. benefits in mitigation
  • Promotes holistic and sustainable planning

docs.title: ⚠️ Environmental and Regulatory Considerations in Floodplain Management¶
docs.text:
Regulation / Agency Role US Army Corps of Engineers (USACE) Responsible for wetland permitting under Section 404 of the Clean Water Act Section 404, Clean Water Act Regulates discharge of dredged or fill material into navigable waters and adjacent wetlands Endangered Species Act (ESA) Managed by US Fish and Wildlife Service and NOAA's National Marine Fisheries Service (NMFS)
  • Local officials enforce Section 404 by investigating illegal dumping or dredging activities reported by citizens.
  • Section 404 prohibits unauthorized discharge of materials into wetlands or navigable waters, protecting ecosystems.

docs.title: Primary Types of Floodplains¶
docs.text:
1. Riverine - flooding that occurs along a channel
  2. Coastal - flooding caused by storm surge and coastal topography
  3. Shallow - flooding in flat areas with poor or no defined drainage

docs.title: Riverine Flooding¶
docs.text:
• Occurs along channels when water overflows banks

  • Features overbank flooding - the most common type of flooding in the US

  • Starts in watershed tributaries and flows downstream

  • May take days for flood crest to reach downstream areas after initial rainfall

  • USGS and other agencies monitor river heights to warn residents

docs.title: Coastal Flooding¶
docs.text:
• Caused by offshore storms (hurricanes, tropical depressions)
  • Influenced by tidal cycles, coastal topography, and bathymetry
  • Creates storm surge - water pushed toward shore by persistent winds and pressure changes
  • Includes tsunamis generated by seismic events
  • Can feature ice floe movements in larger lakes

docs.title: Shallow Flooding¶
docs.text:
• Occurs in areas with little slope and no defined channels
  • Water accumulates and spreads out, causing widespread flooding
  • Often overlooked in dry-season basins or watershed recharge areas
  • Cypress domes are natural depressions prone to this flooding
  • Sheet flow is floodwater that spreads over large areas at relatively uniform depth

docs.title: Flash Flooding¶
docs.text:
• Occurs in hilly/mountainous areas
  • May arrive within minutes after heavy rainfall
  • Also occurs in urban areas due to impervious surfaces and drainage systems

docs.title: Flood Maps and Zones¶
docs.text:
• Base Flood Elevation (BFE): Elevation of the 100-year (1% annual chance) flood

  • Special Flood Hazard Area (SFHA): Base floodplain displayed on FEMA maps (A and V zones)

  • The Limit of Moderate Wave Action (LiMWA) line is crucial for determining construction requirements and flood insurance rates.

    • It represents the inland boundary of an area where 1.5-foot or greater breaking waves are expected during a 1-percent-annual-chance flood event.

docs.title: Standard Flood Zones and Their Meanings¶
docs.text:
• Zone A: Base floodplain with no BFEs provided
  • Zone AE: Base floodplain with BFEs provided (replaces A1-30 on newer maps)
  • Zone AH: Shallow flooding in ponding areas with BFEs
  • Zone AO: Shallow flooding areas with depths provided (not elevations)
  • Zone A1-30: Numbered zones showing BFEs (older maps)
  • Zone A99: Areas protected by levees under construction
  • Zone AR: Areas where flood protection systems are being restored

docs.title: V Zones (Coastal High Hazard Areas)¶
docs.text:
• Zone V: Coastal areas subject to high velocity wave action without BFEs

  • Zone VE: Coastal high hazard areas with BFEs (replaces V1-30)

docs.title: Other Zones¶
docs.text:
• Zone B/X (shaded): Moderate flood hazard (between 100-year and 500-year floods)

  • Zone C/X (unshaded): Minimal flood hazard (above 500-year flood)

  • Zone D: Undetermined but possible flood hazard

docs.title: Flood Map Reading Tips¶
docs.text:
• Reference the map legend for interpretation
  • In Zone AO, numbers indicate depth, not elevation
  • In AH zones, numbers indicate BFE
  • Depth less than 1 foot → Zone B (shallow flooding)
  • Depth 1-3 feet → Zone AO (shallow flooding with ponding)
  • Newer FIRMs use "80s zones" (e.g., AE) instead of older "numbered zones" (A1-30)

docs.title: 📚 Important Concepts and Clarifications¶
docs.text:
• 100-year flood: A flood event with a 1% chance of occurring in any given year. More common than a 500-year flood.
  • 500-year flood: A flood event with a 0.2% chance of occurring in any given year; much rarer.
  • The area between 100-year and 500-year floods is the moderate flood hazard zone (Zone B).
  • Shallow flooding cutoff: Depths less than 1 foot fall into Zone B; depths of 2 feet or more may be classified as AO.
  • Flood zones are often depicted with shading on FIRMs; gray-shaded areas often represent these shallow flood risk zones.
  • Flood zones like B and C are often unshaded or lightly shaded, but their distinctions are important for insurance and planning.

docs.title: Week 1: NFIP and Floodplain Management Quiz¶
docs.text:
1. What are the three major parts (or "pillars") of the NFIP? a) Insurance, Mapping, and Regulation b) Insurance, Recovery, and Enforcement c) Mapping, Monitoring, and Mitigation d) Development, Insurance, and Emergency Response

  2. In the NFIP structure, who develops the policies and laws, and who enforces regulations? a) FEMA develops policies; states enforce regulations b) Federal government develops policies; local communities enforce regulations c) States develop policies; FEMA enforces regulations d) Local communities develop policies; federal authorities enforce regulations

  3. What does the Community Rating System (CRS) affect? a) The level of flood insurance coverage available to homeowners b) The amount of disaster assistance following a flood c) Discount rates for flood insurance through improved floodplain management d) The classification of flood zones in a community

  4. What is the definition of a "floodway"? a) Any area where flooding commonly occurs b) The channel of a river and adjacent land reserved to discharge the base flood without raising water levels significantly c) Areas protected by levees and flood control structures d) The entire 100-year floodplain area

  5. What type of flooding is characterized by water that spreads out over a large area that does not have defined channels? a) Riverine flooding b) Flash flooding c) Sheet flow d) Overbank flooding

  6. What is the difference between hydrostatic and hydrodynamic forces in flooding? a) Hydrostatic forces are vertical, hydrodynamic forces are horizontal b) Hydrostatic forces affect buildings, hydrodynamic forces affect infrastructure c) Hydrostatic is pressure from standing water, hydrodynamic is from moving water d) Hydrostatic forces occur inland, hydrodynamic forces occur in coastal areas

  7. Which flood zone represents coastal areas subject to high-velocity wave action? a. Zone A b. Zone V c. Zone X d. Zone D

  8. What is a correct recommendation for handling basement flooding? a) Pump water out as quickly as possible b) Lower water levels slowly in stages to allow equilibrium c) Add concrete walls to resist water pressure d) Allow basements to fill completely before pumping

  9. What does the letter "E" in Zone AE indicate? a) Elevated risk b) Emergency designation c) Base flood elevations are provided d) Erosion hazard area

  10. Which of the following statements about floodplain mapping is true? a) Zone C is at higher risk than Zone A b) FIRMs show precise (unrounded) BFEs c) FIS is less detailed than FIRMs d) BFEs on FIRMs are typically rounded to the nearest foot

docs.title: Answer Key¶
docs.text:
1. a) Insurance, Mapping, and Regulation
  2. b) Federal government develops policies; local communities enforce regulations
  3. c) Discount rates for flood insurance through improved floodplain management
  4. b) The channel of a river and adjacent land reserved to discharge the base flood without raising water levels significantly
  5. c) Sheet flow
  6. c) Hydrostatic is pressure from standing water, hydrodynamic is from moving water
  7. b) Zone V
  8. b) Lower water levels slowly in stages to allow equilibrium
  9. c) Base flood elevations are provided
  10. d) BFEs on FIRMs are typically rounded to the nearest foot

docs.title: Week 2: Understanding the 1% Chance Flood and Base Flood Elevation¶
docs.text: • Video Reference

docs.title: Base Flood Elevation (BFE) and Floodplain Concepts¶
docs.text:
• Base Flood Elevation (BFE) is defined as the flood having a 1% chance of being equaled or exceeded in any given year.
  • This is also known as the 100-year floodplain or Special Flood Hazard Area (SFHA). All three terms describe the same concept.

docs.title: Understanding the 1% Chance¶
docs.text:
Concept Explanation Common Misunderstanding 1% Chance Flood There is a 1% chance each year that a flood will reach or exceed the BFE It does not mean a flood happens strictly once every 100 years Marble Metaphor If you have 100 marbles, 1 red and 99 white, drawing the red marble is a 1% chance People mistakenly think flooding happens exactly once every 100 years, which is incorrect

Key point: Flooding is a probabilistic event, meaning it can occur multiple times within 100 years or not at all.

docs.title: Freeboard Concept¶
docs.text:
Freeboard is an additional height above the BFE to provide a safety margin against flood uncertainties.

Location Typical Freeboard Requirement Explanation Hillsborough County 6 inches Local ordinance requires building 6 inches above the BFE Some Panhandle Communities 4 feet Higher freeboard requirements due to local risk assessments Putnam Island 3 feet Unique local freeboard based on specific flood risk
  • Freeboard varies by local ordinance and can cause confusion when comparing different areas.
  • Communities often adopt higher freeboard requirements to reduce flood insurance costs through the Community Rating System (CRS).

docs.title: Construction Standards in Flood Zones¶
docs.text:
Zone Construction Requirements Notes A Zone Standard flood-resistant construction practices, elevation per BFE Elevation certificate required, lowest floor elevation measured V (Velocity) Zone More stringent construction standards due to wave action and velocity Coastal areas; requires stronger foundation and impact-resistant materials
  • The Pima Coastal Construction Manual is a recommended reference for construction practices in coastal and flood-prone areas.
  • Elevation certificates document the base flood elevation, finished floor, and lowest horizontal structural member height for regulatory compliance.

docs.title: Flood Insurance Study (FIS) and Flood Insurance Rate Maps (FIRM)¶
docs.text:
Document Purpose Details Flood Insurance Study (FIS) Provides detailed flood profiles and data Contains precise flood elevation profiles (not rounded), hydraulic analysis, flood history, and geographic info Flood Insurance Rate Map (FIRM) Displays general floodplain boundaries Shows rounded BFE numbers, flood zones, floodplain limits
  • The FIS is more detailed and accurate than the FIRM.
  • The BFE on FIRMs is typically rounded to the nearest foot.
  • When asked for regulatory BFE, specify whether it is the FIRM rounded value or the FIS detailed value.

docs.title: Hydraulic Engineering Concepts in Flood Studies¶
Manning's n Value¶
docs.text:
• Describes resistance to water flow in channels and overbank areas.

  • Varies depending on the surface type:

  • Engineers use Manning's n to calculate flow velocities and water surface profiles.

  • You do not need to calculate Manning's n but understand its role in determining flood elevations.

  • The value of Manning's n can range from $0.010$ for smooth, new concrete to $0.100$ for extremely rough, weedy channels.

    | Surface Type | Resistance to Flow (Manning's n) | |-------------|----------------------------------| | Concrete | Low resistance (smooth, fast flow) | | Tall Grass | High resistance (slower flow) | | Rocky Bottom | Moderate resistance | | Mud | Moderate to high resistance |

docs.title: Floodplain Components and Terminology¶
docs.text:
• Floodplain: The area adjoining a river or stream that is subject to flooding during a specific flood event, such as the 100-year flood.

    | Term | Definition | |------|------------| | Floodway | The channel of a river or stream and the adjacent land areas that must be reserved to discharge the base flood without increasing the water surface elevation more than a designated height. | | Fringe | The area of the floodplain outside the floodway where floodwaters may stand but do not flow rapidly. | | 100-year Floodplain | The combined area of the floodway and the fringe; represents the area subject to flooding in a 100-year (1% annual chance) event. | | Stream Channel Bottom (Thalweg) | The lowest point along the length of the stream channel, where the deepest water flows. |

  • Flood fringes are often not symmetrical; this reflects natural river characteristics such as cut slopes and slip-off slopes.

  • Floodplain widths vary greatly in scale: a small local river and a massive river like the Mississippi can have similar schematic representations but vastly different real-world sizes.

docs.title: Floodway and Regulatory Floodway¶
docs.text:
Floodway is the channel of a river or water body and adjacent land areas reserved to discharge the base flood without increasing flood heights significantly.

  • The floodway is a regulated zone where construction and fill are often restricted to prevent increasing flood risk elsewhere.
  • It is defined as causing no more than a designated rise in water surface elevation (typically 1 foot).

docs.title: Building in the Floodway and the No-Rise Concept¶
Can you build in the floodway?¶
docs.text:
• Technically yes, but it is strongly discouraged by the National Flood Insurance Program (NFIP).
  • Building in the floodway requires a no-rise certification.

docs.title: No-Rise Certification¶
docs.text:
A professional engineering study that demonstrates that any construction in the floodway will not increase the base flood water surface elevation beyond a certain allowable rise (usually 1 foot or less, sometimes zero).

  • This study is required to prove the building won't cause increased flooding risks to other properties.

  • The term "no-rise" means the allowed surcharge (rise in water surface) is minimal or zero.

  • Surcharge is the maximum allowable increase in water surface elevation caused by construction in the floodway.

    | Parameter | Description | |-----------|-------------| | Surcharge | The increase in water surface elevation due to floodway encroachment or construction. | | Allowed Surcharge | Typically ≤ 1 foot; some areas may require zero rise (no increase allowed). |

docs.title: Strategies to Comply with No-Rise¶
docs.text:
• Structures may need to be elevated on piers or pilings rather than slab-on-grade to avoid displacing floodwater.

  • Buoyancy calculations are important to ensure buildings don't float away during floods.

docs.title: Hydraulic Parameters in Floodplain Analysis¶
docs.text:
• Regulatory BFE on maps is often a rounded number (e.g., 10 feet).

  • Precise BFE from the FIS data table can be more exact (e.g., 9.9 feet), which may be important for construction decisions to minimize elevation requirements and costs.

    | Parameter | Definition | |-----------|------------| | Distance/Station | Position along the river or stream where data is collected. | | Cross-Section Area | Area of the river cross-section at the given station. | | Mean Velocity | Average water velocity at the cross-section. | | Slope (S) | Energy gradient or bed slope at the cross-section. | | Base Flood Elevation (BFE) | Water surface elevation during the base flood event at the cross-section. | | Surcharge | Increase in water surface elevation caused by floodway encroachment. |

docs.title: Using Flood Insurance Rate Maps (FIRMs) and Flood Insurance Studies (FIS)¶
docs.text:
• The FIS data tables give detailed measurements for each cross-section: station distance, area, velocity, slope (S), base flood elevation (BFE), and surcharge.

  • These tables should be used together with the FIRM for accurate floodplain management.

  • Each river or water body has its own data table (e.g., c table for Rocky River floodplain).

    | Resource | Purpose | |----------|---------| | FIRM (Flood Insurance Rate Map) | Shows floodplain boundaries including floodways and flood fringes on a geographic map. | | FIS (Flood Insurance Study) Data Table | Provides detailed hydraulic data per cross-section (e.g., velocity, cross-sectional area). |

docs.title: Reading Flood Insurance Rate Maps (FIRMs)¶
docs.text:
• Floodway and Fringe Areas are marked with different shading and cross-hatching.

  • Zone designations such as Zone X shaded and Zone X unshaded indicate areas outside the floodplain with different flood risks.

  • The legend on the map clarifies what each symbol and shading means.

  • The black boundary lines on maps can sometimes represent detailed flood zone limits.

docs.title: Key Points About Cross Sections¶
docs.text: Aspect Explanation Location Cross sections represent a specific line perpendicular to the river/stream flow. Measurement Lines When measuring floodway width, measure between the red floodway boundary lines, not between cross-section hexagons or other symbols. Data Correspondence Each cross section shown on the map corresponds to data in a floodway data table, including width and elevation. Distance Along River Distance values in data tables represent distance downstream from a reference point, possibly in feet or miles. Always check units.

docs.title: Important Considerations for Measurements and Data Interpretation¶
docs.text: Topic Explanation Measuring Floodway Width Measure between the red boundary lines on the map, not across hexagons or other map symbols. Width Data Source The exact width of a cross section is found in the floodway data table, not by measuring on the map. Distance Units Distance downstream in flood data tables may be in feet or miles. Always verify the units. Reference Points Distances are measured from a known station, confluence, or benchmark along the river. Zone Differences Differences between shaded and unshaded Zones X relate to topography and historical flood data. Potential Errors Sometimes units or labels in data tables may be inconsistent or unclear; always cross-check.

docs.title: Practical Usage Example¶
docs.text:
If asked: "What is the width of cross section A?"

  • Do not measure the map directly.

  • Consult the floodway data table in the Flood Insurance Study; it will list the width explicitly.

  • For example: width = 115 feet.

docs.title: Map and Data Table Integration¶
docs.text:
Map Element Corresponding Data Table Element Cross-section hexagon (e.g., A) Cross-section data row labeled with the same letter (e.g., A) Floodway boundary red lines Floodway width and elevation data

| Distance downstream | Distance values in the floodway data table (check for units!)

docs.title: Additional Notes¶
docs.text:
• The term "thalweg" refers to the lowest point in the river channel where the deepest flow occurs.
  • Rivers are naturally asymmetrical, so floodplain fringes will often be uneven, reflecting natural features like cut banks and depositional bars.
  • Always use the legend and data tables together for accurate interpretation.

docs.title: Week 2: Understanding the 1% Chance Flood Quiz¶
docs.text:
1. The Base Flood Elevation (BFE) is defined as: a) The highest recorded flood in a community's history b) The flood that has a 1% chance of being equaled or exceeded in any given year c) The average flood level over a 100-year period d) The flood that occurs exactly once every 100 years

  2. Which of the following is NOT a term used to describe the same concept as the "100-year floodplain"? a) Base Flood Elevation (BFE) b) Special Flood Hazard Area (SFHA) c) 1% annual chance floodplain d) 500-year floodplain

  3. The "marble metaphor" for understanding the 1% chance flood means: a) There is exactly one flood every 100 years b) The chance of flooding increases over time c) If you have 100 marbles with 1 red, drawing the red marble is like the 1% chance of flooding in any given year d) The odds of flooding are random and cannot be predicted

  4. Modern methods to determine BFE include which advanced tools? a) Satellite imagery and GPS only b) Field surveys and topographic sheets c) LiDAR and radar d) Flood gauges and stream monitoring

  5. What is "freeboard" in floodplain management? a) The highest level a flood has historically reached b) The minimum elevation for constructing buildings in a coastal zone c) An additional height above the BFE to provide a safety margin d) The distance between the water surface and the bottom of a bridge

  6. What percentage of flood insurance claims occur in Floodplain X (outside the SFHA)? a) 5% b) 10% c) 25% d) 50%

  7. What is required when building in a floodway? a) Special flood insurance b) Approval from FEMA c) No-rise certification d) Concrete foundations

  8. What does the term "no-rise" mean in floodplain development? a) Buildings must be elevated above the BFE b) The allowed surcharge (rise in water surface) is minimal or zero c) New buildings cannot be constructed in the floodplain d) Water cannot enter the building during a flood event

  9. On Flood Insurance Rate Maps (FIRMs), cross sections are always shown as: a) Squares b) Lines c) Hexagons d) Triangles

  10. When measuring floodway width on a map, you should measure between: a) Cross section hexagons b) River banks c) Red floodway boundary lines d) Zone designation labels

docs.title: Answer Key¶
docs.text:
1. b) The flood that has a 1% chance of being equaled or exceeded in any given year
  2. d) 500-year floodplain
  3. c) If you have 100 marbles with 1 red, drawing the red marble is like the 1% chance of flooding in any given year
  4. c) LiDAR and radar
  5. c) An additional height above the BFE to provide a safety margin
  6. c) 25%
  7. c) No-rise certification
  8. b) The allowed surcharge (rise in water surface) is minimal or zero
  9. c) Hexagons
  10. c) Red floodway boundary lines

docs.title: Flood Insurance Rate Maps (FIRMs) Study Guide¶
docs.text: • Video Reference

docs.title: Cross-Sections and Transects¶
docs.text:
• Transect: A profile line running from inland across the shoreline to the limit of wave action

  • Velocity Zone (V Zone): Areas with wave heights greater than 3 feet; characterized by higher velocities due to wave action

  • Wave Height Zones:

    | Wave Height | Zone | Description | |-------------|------|-------------| | Greater than 3 feet | V Zone | High velocity zone with strong wave action | | Less than 3 feet | A Zone (Coastal) | Moderate wave action; sometimes called Coastal A zone or LIMWA (Limit of Moderate Wave Action) |

docs.title: Wave Run-up¶
docs.text:
• The vertical extent waves travel up the shore beyond the still water line
  • Varies based on:
    • Shoreline slope and shape
    • Storm characteristics and direction
    • Astronomical tides
    • Water depth offshore
  • Important for flood risk assessment and construction considerations

docs.title: Roughness and Flow Velocity¶
docs.text:
• Manning's Roughness Coefficient: Scale used to estimate flow velocity based on surface roughness

  • Critical for calculating water velocity in channels and floodways

  • Roughness varies with surface types:

    | Surface Type | Roughness Impact | |-------------|------------------| | Tall Grass | Increased roughness, slows flow | | Concrete | Low roughness, faster flow | | Regular Grass | Moderate roughness |

docs.title: Floodway and Profile Details¶
docs.text:
• Floodways are shown on maps but usually absent on FIS
  • Profiles show elevations along a river or stream, including:
    • Bridge crossings (depicted as I-beams) with bottom and top elevations
    • Flood profiles are used to determine Base Flood Elevations (BFE)

docs.title: Fundamentals of Flood Insurance Rate Maps (FIRMs)¶
Community and NFIP Identification¶
docs.text:
• FIRMs often cover multiple communities within a county
  • Each community has a unique NFIP identification number
  • Map identification includes:
    • Community name
    • County name
    • NFIP ID number
  • Important for documentation like elevation certificates and regulatory compliance

docs.title: Map Revision Letters¶
docs.text:
• Each community's map revision is indicated by a letter suffix (e.g., A, B, C, D)
  • Letter corresponds to revision number for that community, not the entire map
  • Always check the revision letter for the latest version
  • The word "revision" is not explicitly written; the letter alone signifies it

docs.title: Effective Date¶
docs.text:
• Displayed on the front page of the map
  • Using the most recent effective map is mandatory under NFIP rules
  • Communities not using the latest map may violate federal regulations

docs.title: Legend and Map Symbols¶
docs.text:
• Legend: Essential for interpreting the map, though students don't need to memorize it

  • Key symbols include:

    | Symbol | Meaning | |--------|---------| | Gray box with diagonal lines | Floodway area | | Shaded areas with hole | Zone X shaded (areas of minimal flood hazard) | | Area labeled "X" (unshaded) | Zone X unshaded: areas outside flood hazard | | B Zone | Areas with flooding but less severe than A or V zones | | D Zone | Areas with possible but undetermined flood hazard |

docs.title: Profile Interpretation and Applications¶
docs.text:
• Profiles help determine flood elevations at specific points like road crossings

  • Elevation lines (500-year, 100-year, 10-year flood elevations) are shown on profiles

  • Bridge crossings are precisely drawn to scale with bottom and top elevations

  • Profiles allow interpolation of exact flood elevations between known points

docs.title: Coastal Barrier Resource Areas (CBRA) and Otherwise Protected Areas (OPA)¶
docs.text:
• Designated coastal zones protected from development to conserve resources and reduce federal flood insurance exposure

  • Effective dates: 1983, 1990, 1991 (different areas)

  • Buildings constructed or substantially improved after these dates are not eligible for federal flood insurance

  • Marked on flood maps by diagonal crosshatching or solid diagonal lines

  • Different types of hatched areas correspond to different effective designation years

docs.title: Practical Implications¶
docs.text:
• Existing buildings built before designation dates may have flood insurance

  • Substantially damaged buildings rebuilt after the effective date cannot get flood insurance

  • Communities may allow construction permits, but federal flood insurance won't be available

  • This affects financing, as federally-backed loans usually require flood insurance

  • Owners may need private insurance or self-insurance

docs.title: Cross Sections¶
docs.text:
• Slices or profiles of the floodplain used to analyze river/stream flood characteristics

  • Marked by hexagons on maps and labeled with letters (A, B, C) and numbers

  • Direction usually follows river flow downstream, but not always

  • Check the stationing distance (reference point) on the map or profile

  • Do not assume cross sections always increase in distance downstream without verification

docs.title: Map Scale and Measurement¶
docs.text:
• Scales vary between maps (e.g., 500 feet, 1000 feet)
  • Use a piece of paper to mark distances for rough measurements
  • Some maps may not be to scale
  • Always verify scale on map legend before making distance estimates

docs.title: Finding Base Flood Elevation (BFE) Step-by-Step¶
docs.text:
1. Locate the River on the Map

    • Identify the specific river
    • Don't confuse with other rivers on the map

  2. Find the Correct Cross Section

    • Cross sections marked with hexagons and letters
    • Verify you're on the correct river

  3. Check the Floodway on the Map

    • Designated by diagonal lines
    • Base Flood Elevation in the floodway is your target

  4. Read the Elevation on the FIRM

    • Locate elevation numbers along the river
    • Example: Elevation near cross section A might be approximately 10 ft

  5. Consult the Profile if Needed

    • Profiles show flood elevations vs. cross sections
    • Use profile lines for 10-, 50-, 100-, and 500-year floods

  6. Use the Floodway Data Table for Regulatory Numbers

    • For BFE in the floodway, the data table is authoritative
    • The profile may not always give the regulatory floodway elevation accurately

docs.title: Common Pitfalls & Reminders¶
docs.text:
• Confusing rivers with same cross section letters: Always verify the river name
  • Ignoring "floodway" in questions: Read carefully; "floodway" specifies using the floodway data table
  • Misreading elevation lines on profiles: Identify the correct line style for the 100-year flood
  • Assuming the first cross section with a letter is correct: Trace back to the correct river

docs.title: Letters of Map Change (LOMC)¶
docs.text:
• LOMA (Letter of Map Amendment): Updates boundaries using better topography; doesn't change BFEs
  • LOMR (Letter of Map Revision): Revises BFEs and boundaries due to physical changes
  • CLOMR (Conditional Letter of Map Revision): Pre-approval before construction
  • LOMR-F (Letter of Map Revision Based on Fill): Revises maps after fill is placed

docs.title: Authority and Environmental Compliance¶
docs.text:
• Only FEMA can officially change flood maps
  • Local governments can request changes but lack authority to make them
  • Changes must consider the Endangered Species Act and other environmental regulations
  • Development impacting protected species may be denied despite meeting floodplain criteria

docs.title: Key Vocabulary¶
docs.text:
• Floodway: Channel and adjacent lands that must remain free of encroachment for base flood discharge
  • Base Flood Elevation (BFE): Computed elevation of floodwater during the base (100-year) flood
  • FIRM: Official map showing flood hazard areas and floodway boundaries
  • Profile: Graphical representation of flood elevations along a river or stream
  • Culvert: Man-made structure allowing water flow under a road or obstruction

docs.title: Important Reminders¶
docs.text:
• Always check questions carefully to determine which source to use (profile, floodway table, or map)
  • Interpret elevation data from profiles by reading the scale carefully
  • Understand the difference between floodplain and floodway
  • Know how to locate floodway limits on the FIRM map

docs.title: Week 4 - NFIP and Floodplain Management¶
docs.text: • Video Reference

docs.title: Overview of NFIP Requirements¶
docs.text:
• NFIP: National Flood Insurance Program.
  • CFR: Code of Federal Regulations, specifically 44 CFR is crucial for understanding NFIP.
  • Subsection 60-70: Detailed requirements found in 24 CFR.

docs.title: Step 1: Handling Areas Without Maps¶
docs.text:
• 60.3(a): Communities without maps must have officials determine if areas are reasonably safe from flooding.
    • Responsibility falls on local officials (building officials, floodplain administrators, mayors).
    • Challenges: Balancing safety and community development costs.

docs.title: Clean Water Act¶
docs.text:
• Enforcement: U.S. Army Corps of Engineers (USACE).
  • Importance: Regulates construction near navigable waters.

docs.title: Executive Order 11988 (1986)¶
docs.text:
• Purpose: Requires federal agencies to assess if projects are in the 100 or 500-year floodplain and explore alternative sites.

  • Example: Building federal projects (e.g., libraries, nuclear power plants) outside floodplains is crucial due to potential flooding impacts.

    | Project Type | Floodplain Considerations | |-------------|---------------------------| | Federal Prisons | Floodplain concerns may arise. | | Federal Libraries | Must avoid floodplains to protect investments. | | Nuclear Power Plants | Critical to avoid floodplain locations. |

docs.title: Step 2: Base Flood Elevation (BFE) Requirements¶
docs.text:
• Permit Requirement: Any development in an approximate zone requires a permit.
  • Base Flood Elevation Data: Developers must provide this if no maps are available.
    • Thresholds:
      • 50 Lots or 5 acres, whichever is less.

docs.title: Example of Lot Considerations¶
docs.text: Scenario Requirement 51 Lots, 4 acres Requires BFE data. 49 Lots, 6 acres Requires BFE data. 50 Lots, 5 acres Requires BFE data.

docs.title: Records and Documentation¶
docs.text:
• Elevation Certificates: Required to document the lowest floor elevation of structures.

    • Retention: Must be kept indefinitely with no statute of limitations.
    • In A zones, 1st floor is TOP of bottom floor.
    • In V zones , 1st floor is BOTTOM of lowest horizontal structure member

docs.title: Additional Considerations¶
docs.text:
• Manufactured Homes: Must adhere to specific NFIP standards.

  • Venting Requirements: For areas beneath the lowest floor.

    • Hydraulic Ports:
      • Minimum of two vents required.
      • Area: 1 square inch for every square foot of enclosed space.

    | Area Size | Venting Requirement | |-----------|---------------------| | 1,000 square feet | 1,000 square inches of venting needed. | | 500 square feet | 500 square inches of venting needed. |

docs.title: Common Issues and Misunderstandings¶
docs.text:
• Misconceptions about venting and elevation requirements can lead to violations.
  • Example: Incorrect installations (plywood blocking vents) may not meet NFIP standards.

docs.title: Key Takeaways¶
docs.text:
• Always ensure projects adhere to NFIP guidelines and standards.
  • Local officials play a critical role in floodplain management, particularly in areas lacking maps.
  • Understanding and documentation of flood elevation and venting requirements are essential for compliance and safety.

docs.title: Introduction to Floodplain Management¶
docs.text: "Floodplain management involves regulating land use in areas that are prone to flooding, ensuring safety and compliance with federal and local regulations."

docs.title: Key Terms and Concepts¶
docs.text:
• Flood Hazard Areas: Regions identified as being at risk for flooding, often designated by specific zones (e.g., A, B, V zones).
  • Recreational Vehicles (RVs): Vehicles that can be parked in flood hazard areas under certain conditions, specifically:
    • Must be on-site for fewer than 180 consecutive days.
    • Must be fully licensed and ready for highway use.

docs.title: RV Regulations in Flood Hazard Areas¶
docs.text:
• Conditions for RVs:
    • If parked long-term, they must comply with the permit requirements for permanent construction.
    • RVs need to be roadworthy; if not, citations may be issued.

docs.title: Example Scenario¶
docs.text: "If an RV has a dead battery, a citation may not be issued. However, if it is not roadworthy (e.g., wheels off, skirting around it), a citation is likely."

docs.title: Designation of Flood Zones¶
docs.text: Zone Type Description A Zone Areas subject to flooding; requires specific construction standards. B Zone Areas with lesser flooding risk; different standards apply. V Zone Coastal areas with high-velocity flood risks; must meet stringent regulations.

docs.title: Key Construction Requirements¶
docs.text:
• Elevation Standards:

    • Structures in V zones must have the bottom of the lowest horizontal structural member at or above the Base Flood Elevation (BFE).
    • New construction must be landward of high tide.

  • Engineering Certification:

    • Required for construction in B zones, it verifies compliance with flood regulations.
    • Must be signed and sealed by a licensed engineer or architect.

docs.title: Foundation Types and Measurements¶
docs.text:
• Lowest Horizontal Structural Member:

    • Important for determining compliance with flood elevation requirements.

  • Measurements:

    • In A zones, measure from the top of the finished floor slab.
    • In V zones, measure from the bottom of the concrete slab.

docs.title: Example of Measurement¶
docs.text: "In the V zone, the bottom of the slab is measured for compliance, even if it seems counterintuitive."

docs.title: Importance of Elevation Certificates¶
docs.text:
"Elevation certificates provide formal documentation of compliance with floodplain regulations."

  • Who Completes the Certificate:
    • Typically completed by land surveyors, engineers, or architects.
    • Community officials rarely sign these due to potential conflicts of interest.

docs.title: Considerations When Completing Elevation Certificates¶
docs.text: Scenario Action Surveyor can't access crawlspace Use alternative documentation or contact the floodplain administrator. Required data fields Must include accurate elevation measurements and flood zone designation.

docs.title: Understanding Basements¶
docs.text: "A basement is defined as a floor level that is below ground on all sides, regardless of its use."

docs.title: Important Considerations¶
docs.text:
• Living Spaces:

    • Even if used for living purposes, if a floor is below grade on all sides, it is classified as a basement.

  • Examples of Basements:

    • A walk-out basement on three sides is still considered a basement.
    • Sunken living rooms that are below grade on all sides are also classified as basements.

docs.title: Documentation Requirements¶
docs.text:
• Retention of Elevation Certificates:

    • No statute of limitations; must be stored securely for compliance.

  • Archival of Maps:

    • Important for historical reference and compliance; communities should keep old maps for future determinations.

docs.title: Benefits of Electronic Storage¶
docs.text: "While not required, storing documents electronically can earn points in the Community Rating System (CRS) for floodplain management."

docs.title: Conclusion on Record-Keeping¶
docs.text: • Retaining accurate records is crucial for compliance and historical reference, particularly when assessing structures built many years ago.

docs.title: Overview of Section 60.3¶
docs.text: Section 60.3 of the NFIP regulations outlines the specific floodplain management criteria that communities must adopt to participate in the NFIP. The requirements are progressive and increase based on the type of flood hazard data provided to the community.

docs.title: 60.3(a) — Communities Without FIRMs or FHBMs¶
docs.text:
• Communities must require permits for all proposed construction or development.
  • Must review permit applications to determine if the proposed construction will be reasonably safe from flooding.
  • Utilize any available data from federal, state, or other sources to identify flood-prone areas.
  • Ensure all new construction is designed and adequately anchored to prevent flotation, collapse, or lateral movement.
  • Use flood-resistant materials and methods.

docs.title: 60.3(b) — Communities With FHBMs But No FIRMs¶
docs.text:
• All requirements of 60.3(a) apply.
  • Requires development permits in SFHA areas.
  • Verification that encroachments don't increase flood levels during a 100-year flood.
  • New construction must be elevated to or above the BFE.
  • Prohibits encroachments in floodways if they would increase flood levels.

docs.title: 60.3(c) — Communities With FIRMs and BFEs¶
docs.text:
• All requirements of 60.3(a) and (b) apply.
  • New construction must have lowest floor elevated to or above the BFE.
  • Manufactured homes must be installed using methods that minimize flood damage.
  • Non-residential structures can be floodproofed instead of elevated if certified by an engineer.
  • Prohibits new construction in floodways that would increase base flood elevations.

docs.title: 60.3(d) — Communities With FIRMs, BFEs, and Floodways¶
docs.text:
• All requirements of 60.3(a), (b), and (c) apply.
  • No encroachments in floodways unless certified by an engineer that there will be no increase in flood levels.
  • Communities must obtain and review detailed hydraulic data for all proposed developments.
  • Must notify adjacent communities and state coordinating agencies before altering watercourses.

docs.title: 60.3(e) — Communities With Coastal High Hazard Areas (V Zones)¶
docs.text:
• All requirements of 60.3(a), (b), (c), and (d) apply.
  • New construction must be located landward of the mean high tide line.
  • Structures must be elevated on pilings/columns and have space beneath the lowest floor free of obstructions.
  • No use of fill for structural support.
  • No alteration of sand dunes or mangrove stands that would increase flood damage.

docs.title: Key Enforcement Points for Floodplain Administrators¶
docs.text:
• Substantial Improvement/Damage: Any reconstruction, rehabilitation, addition, or other improvement of a structure where the cost equals or exceeds 50% of the market value of the structure before the improvement or damage occurred.
  • Cumulative Substantial Improvement: Some communities track cumulative improvements over time. If they collectively exceed 50% of value, the structure must be brought into compliance.
  • Freeboard: Additional height (typically 1-3 feet) above the BFE required by many communities for safety margin.
  • Critical Facilities: Special treatment for facilities like hospitals, fire stations, emergency operations centers, etc. Often required to be elevated higher than standard structures.

docs.title: Common Compliance Issues¶
docs.text:
• Enclosure Violations: Using areas below BFE for purposes other than parking, storage, or building access.
  • Venting Problems: Insufficient flood vents or improper installation of vents.
  • Elevation Certificate Errors: Inaccurate measurements or misidentification of the lowest floor.
  • Improper Wet Floodproofing: Using inappropriate materials or techniques below the BFE.
  • Fill Issues: Improper placement or inadequate compaction of fill material.

docs.title: Community Rating System (CRS) Connection to Section 60.3¶
docs.text:
Communities that adopt floodplain management standards that exceed the minimum requirements of Section 60.3 may qualify for reduced flood insurance premiums through the CRS. Some credited activities include:

  • Adopting higher freeboard requirements
  • Implementing stricter standards for critical facilities
  • Requiring compensatory storage for fill in the floodplain
  • More restrictive floodway encroachment standards
  • Protection of floodplain functions and natural areas
  • Higher substantial damage/improvement thresholds

docs.title: Documentation Requirements for Section 60.3 Compliance¶
docs.text:
• Building Permits: Must document elevation requirements and construction standards.
  • Variance Procedures: Must have clear criteria and review process for variance requests.
  • As-Built Certifications: Required to verify that construction meets approved plans.
  • Inspection Records: Document site visits during construction phases.
  • Violation Notices: Formal documentation of non-compliance and remedial actions.
  • Floodplain Development Permits: Separate from or integrated with building permits.

docs.title: 🔐 GitLab SSH Setup — Windows & Linux/macOS¶
docs.text: • Goal: create/load an SSH key, add it to GitLab, and verify with ssh -T git@gitlab.com.

docs.title: Prereqs¶
docs.text:
• Git installed

    • Windows: [Git for Windows] (includes Git Bash + OpenSSH)

    • Linux/macOS: Git + OpenSSH are usually preinstalled

  • A GitLab account

docs.title: Check if you already have an SSH key¶
docs.text:
• Linux / macOS / Windows (Git Bash)

    ls -al ~/.ssh

  • Windows (PowerShell)

    Get-ChildItem ~\.ssh

  • Look for a key pair like id_ed25519 (private) and id_ed25519.pub (public).

  • Typical locations:

    • Linux/macOS: ~/.ssh/

    • Windows: C:\Users\<You>\.ssh\

docs.title: Generate a new key (if you don’t have one)¶
docs.text:
• Use Ed25519 as demo

  • Linux / macOS / Windows (Git Bash) / - Windows (PowerShell)

    ssh-keygen -t ed25519 -C "you@example.com"

  • Result: id_ed25519 and id_ed25519.pub created in your ~/.ssh (or C:\Users\<You>\.ssh)

docs.title: Start the SSH agent & add your key¶
docs.text:
• Linux / macOS / Windows (Git Bash)

    # start agent in this shell.
eval "$(ssh-agent -s)"
# add your key
ssh-add ~/.ssh/id_ed25519
    • If you get “no such file,” double-check the path/filename.

  • Windows (PowerShell)

    # make the agent run automatically
Get-Service ssh-agent | Set-Service -StartupType Automatic
Start-Service ssh-agent

# add your key
ssh-add $env:USERPROFILE\.ssh\id_ed25519

docs.title: Copy your public key and add to GitLab¶
docs.text:
• Open the .pub file and copy all its contents

  • Then in GitLab: User menu → Settings → SSH Keys → Add new key (paste, give a title, Save).

docs.title: Test the connection¶
docs.text:
• Linux / macOS / Windows

    ssh -T git@gitlab.com

  • Expected success message:

    Welcome to GitLab, @your-username!

  • If you see Permission denied (publickey), the key either isn’t added to GitLab or not loaded in the agent.

docs.title: Troubleshooting tips¶
docs.text:
• Agent says no identities → run ssh-add again (see Step 3)

  • Permissions on Linux/macOS (rarely the issue on Windows)

    chmod 700 ~/.ssh
chmod 600 ~/.ssh/id_ed25519
chmod 644 ~/.ssh/id_ed25519.pub

  • Multiple keys? Create ~/.ssh/config

    Host gitlab.com
    HostName gitlab.com
    User git
    IdentityFile ~/.ssh/id_ed25519
    IdentitiesOnly yes

docs.title: 🚀 GitLab: From Local Folder to Remote Repo¶
📂 Initialize a Local Repository¶
docs.text:
• Navigate to your project folder in the terminal

    cd /path/to/your/folder
git init

  • This makes your folder a Git repository, then add your files and make the first commit:

    git add .
git commit -m "Initial commit"

docs.title: 🖥️ Create a New Project on GitLab¶
docs.text:
1. Go to GitLab
  2. Click New project → Create blank project.
  3. Enter a name (e.g., my-project).
  4. Don’t add README if you already have one locally.(If you do add one, see Section 5.)

docs.title: 🔗 Connect Local Repo to GitLab¶
docs.text:
• On the GitLab project page, copy the repo URL:

    • HTTPS example:

      git remote add origin https://gitlab.com/username/my-project.git

    • SSH example (recommended):

      git remote add origin git@gitlab.com:username/my-project.git

docs.title: 🚀 Push to GitLab¶
docs.text:
git branch -M main      # Ensure branch is called main
    git push -u origin main
  • Your project is now on GitLab 🎉

docs.title: ⚡ Fixing the README Conflict¶
docs.text:
• If you created your GitLab repo with a README, you’ll see this error when pushing:

    fatal: refusing to merge unrelated histories

  • Solution: Merge histories

    git pull origin main --allow-unrelated-histories
    • Resolve conflicts if prompted.

  • Then push again:

    git push -u origin main

  • Alternative: Overwrite remote (⚠ destructive)

    git push -u origin main --force
    • Only use this if you don’t need the GitLab README or other remote history.

docs.title: 🛠️ Common Git Commands Cheat Sheet¶
docs.text:
• Check repo status

    git status

  • See commit history

    git log --oneline --graph --all

  • Pull latest changes

    git pull

  • Stage & commit changes

    git add .
git commit -m "Your message"
git push

docs.title: ✅ Summary¶
docs.text:
1. git init → create local repo
  2. git add . && git commit -m "Initial commit" → commit files
  3. Create GitLab project
  4. git remote add origin <repo_url> → connect remote
  5. git push -u origin main → upload files
  6. Set up SSH for easier pushes
  7. Use --allow-unrelated-histories if GitLab created a README

docs.title: Linux file system¶
docs.text: • The Linux file system adheres to the File Hierarchy Structure (FHS), which organizes directories and files in a standardized manner, naming them after their function or content.

docs.title: Linux Directory Structure¶
docs.text:
1. / (Root): This is the top-level directory of the file system. All other directories are nested beneath this one.

  2. /bin (User Binaries): Contains essential user command binaries (programs) that are needed for the system to boot up and run.

    • /sbin: Stands for "system binaries" and contains essential system administration binaries. These commands are not intended for regular users but for the root and system maintenance purposes.

  3. /etc (Configuration Files): Houses system-wide configuration files and directories.

    • It typically contains the configuration files for all the software on your system.

  4. /home (User Home Directories): Holds the personal directories of all users who have an account on the system, except for the root user.

  5. /boot: Contains files needed to start up the system, including the Linux kernel, an initial RAM disk image (for drivers needed at startup), and the bootloader.

    • In simple terms, this is where the files necessary for booting the system are stored.

  6. /opt (Optional Software): Generally contains third-party software that doesn't conform to the standard system structure.

    • Software inside /opt is static and does not change frequently.

  7. /tmp (Temporary Files): Used to store temporary files created by system and user applications.

  8. /var (Variable Files): Intended for files that are expected to grow over time. This includes log files, spool files, and cached data.

  9. /dev: This is a special directory which contains device nodes.

    • It's a way for the Linux kernel to provide access to the hardware of the system via these files.
    • For example, /dev/sda typically represents the first SATA drive.

  10. /usr (User Binaries and Libraries): Contains user commands, their libraries, documentation, etc. It is the second major hierarchy after the root.

    • /usr/local: This hierarchy is for use by the system administrator when installing software locally. It should mimic the structure of /usr. These are usually software or programs that are installed from source, or manually by the sysadmin.

docs.title: What's Vim?¶
docs.text: Vim is an acronym for Vi IMproved. It is a free and open-source cross-platform text editor.

docs.title: How to Install Vim¶
docs.text:
• Vim comes pre-installed on most *nix operating systems. But if it's not installed on your system, you can install it with a package manager of your choice.

  • Here's the installation command for based operating systems:

    sudo apt-get update
sudo apt-get install vim

  • To ensure that it's installed properly, run which vim and you should get /usr/bin/vim in your output.

docs.title: Get Started with Vim¶
docs.text: • enter vim into the editor

docs.title: Vim Modes¶
docs.text:
There are many modes in Vim. But, we'll be looking at the 4 most important modes.

  1. Command Mode
    • This is the default mode (also called Normal mode) in Vim.
    • Basically, to switch from one mode to another, you have to come to Command Mode first and then navigate to the other mode.
    • The commands that you run without any prefix (colon) indicate that you're running the command in command mode.
  2. Command-Line Mode
    • You can use this mode to play around with some commands.
    • commands in this mode are prefixed with a colon (:).
    • You can switch to this mode by pressing : (colon) in command mode.
  3. Insert Mode
    • This mode is used to edit the contents of the file.
    • You can switch to insert mode by pressing i from command mode.
    • You can use the Esc key to switch back to command mode
  4. Visual Mode
    • You can switch to this mode by pressing v from the command mode.

docs.title: Create a New File¶
docs.text:
1. run vim to get into Vim

  2. run :edit sample.txt to create a new file

  3. After running that command, you'll be in command mode

  4. To add some text to the created file, press i to insert mode

    • In this mode, you can type whatever you want into the file.

docs.title: Save a File¶
docs.text:
1. To save a file, you have to switch from Insert mode to Command Line mode.

    • To switch to Command mode from Insert mode, you have to press the Esc key.

  2. To save the file, use command :W

docs.title: Exit Vim¶
docs.text:
• The proper way to close the file and the Vim editor is by using the command: :q

  • Alternatively, you can use a command that's the combination of the above 2 commands (save & quit) to quickly save and quit Vim. :wq

docs.title: Edit a File in Vim¶
docs.text:
• To edit a file, you have to open the file using Vim and switch to Insert mode.
  1. Let's open the sample.txt file using vim sample.txt
  2. pressing i from the Command mode will switch to Insert mode.
  3. Type anything you want
  4. Press Esc on the keyboard and type :w to save the file and :q to quit Vim.

docs.title: Close the file without saving the changes¶
docs.text: • To close the file without saving the changes, you have to run :q! from Command mode.

docs.title: Cut, Copy, and Paste Text from a File using Vim¶
docs.text:
1. Enter Visual mode by pressing the v key on the keyboard.

  2. Move your cursor, Visual mode highlights the text from the beginning up to your cursor.

  3. hit y to copy the text or hit d to cut the text.

  4. Move the cursor to the place where you want to paste the text.

  5. Press p (in lowercase) to paste the text after the cursor and P (in uppercase) to paste the text before the cursor.

  6. Press :wq to save and close the file

docs.title: Other useful shortcut¶
docs.text:
1. yy: copy current line

    • 8yy: copy 8 lines, start from current line
    • y$ : copy from the current position to the end of the line
    • y^ : copy from the start of the line to the current position
    • yw : copy by word (vocabulary)
      • w : jump to next word (start)
      • e : jump tp next word (end)

  2. x (lower case): cut current character (backwards)

    • X (upper case) : cut current character (forwards)

  3. dd: delete current line

    • 3dd: delete 3 lines, start from current line

  4. u: retrieve previous modification

  5. r(lower case): replace current character

  6. Shift + ^ ： Move to the start of the line

    • Shift + $ : Move to the end of the line

  7. gg: Move to the first line

    • Shift + H: Move to the first line
    • L: Move to the last line

  8. :set nu : show the line number

    • set nonu: drop the line number

  9. /[keyword]: search keyword

    • n: jump to next search result

  10. :s/[keyword]/[replace keyword]: replace the first matched keyword as second input

    • :s/[keyword]/[replace keyword]/g : replace all matched keywords as second input (same line)
    • :%s/[keyword]/[replace keyword]/g : replace all matched keywords as second input (whole file)

docs.title: Check IP and Gateway¶
docs.text:
• ipconfig: Check both ip address for host and virtual machine (Windows)
  • ifconfig: Check both ip address for host and virtual machine (Linux)
  • ping + [Target ip] : Check the connection between host and virtual machine

docs.title: Bridged vs Network Address Translation (NAT) vs Host¶
Bridged Mode¶
docs.text:
• Bridged mode allows the virtual machine to appear as a separate device on the host network.

  • It's as if the virtual machine has its own network adapter and IP address, independent of the host.

  • Bridged mode is suitable for scenarios where you need the virtual machine to be fully visible and accessible on the network, such as running server applications that need to be reachable from other devices.

  • Advantages

    • Virtual machines in bridged mode can communicate directly with other devices on the network, including other virtual machines and physical machines.

  • Disadvantages

    • Bridged mode requires assigning IP address to virtual machine
    • Since virtual machines in bridged mode appear as separate devices on the network, they are susceptible to the same security risks as physical machines.

docs.title: Network Address Translation (NAT)¶
docs.text:
• NAT mode allows the virtual machine to share the host's IP address for outbound connections

  • while incoming traffic is routed to the virtual machine based on port forwarding rules.

  • NAT mode is suitable for scenarios where you need internet connectivity for the virtual machine but don't require direct inbound access from the network, such as browsing the web or downloading updates.

  • Advantages

    • NAT mode provides internet connectivity to virtual machines without needing multiple public IP addresses. (created a local network)
    • It adds an extra layer of security by hiding the virtual machine's IP address behind the host's IP address.

  • Disadvantages

    • External network can not access the virtual machine directly.

docs.title: Host-Only Mode¶
docs.text: • Created a private network between host and virtual machine, can not access the external network.

docs.title: Why we need static IP instead of dynamic?¶
docs.text: 1. In a server mode, we do want to dynamically assign device IP address, we want every node (especially the virtual machine, since we need access them very often through the host) have a static IP for testing and maintenance purpose.

docs.title: Change the Internet configuration file in Linux¶
docs.text:
1. su: activate superuser authority

  2. vim etc/sysconfig/network-scripts/ifcfg-ens33

  3. Change BootProTO from dhcp to static

  4. Add information about IP, Gateway and DNS

    • IPADDR = [Your wanted IP address]
    • GATEWAY = [Your wanted Gateway address]
    • DNS1 = [Your wanted DNS address]

  5. reset the network service to activate our setting

    • service network restart

  6. ping to check if the network is working

docs.title: Change the host name¶
docs.text:
• Give every node a better memorable name is much convenient than access using IP address
  • hostname : return the current host name

  1. change hostname config file

    • vim /etc/hostname : access the config file to change the hostname

  2. change hostname using built-in tool

    • hostnamectl set-hostname "[your hostname]"

docs.title: Save hostname and corresponding IP to config file¶
docs.text:
1. vim /etc/hosts : get into the config file

  2. Change the host file in Windows as well

    • find the config file
    • add node name and IP

docs.title: Connect host / node using SSH / Xshell¶
docs.text:
1. Connect to node
    • ssh [user name]@[node name]
    • Use Xshell
  2. Transfer file
    • scp [options] [user@]host1:]source_file_or_directory ... [[user@]host2:]destination
    • Use Xftp

docs.title: 04-System-manage
docs.text: In [ ]: Copied!

docs.title: Process¶
docs.text: • A process in Linux is an instance of a running program. It is the basic unit of execution in Linux, and the Linux kernel manages multiple processes concurrently, giving the illusion of multitasking.

docs.title: Key Characteristics:¶
docs.text:
• PID: Each process is identified by a Process ID (PID), a unique number.
  • Parent-Child Relationship: Processes have a hierarchical structure, where a process can spawn child processes.
  • States: A process can be in one of several states, such as running, sleeping, stopped, or zombie.
  • Environment: Each process operates within a specific environment that includes environment variables, a current directory, and user permissions.

docs.title: Working with Processes¶
docs.text:
1. Listing Processes: You can list processes using commands like ps and top.
    • ps : provides a snapshot of current processes.
    • top : displays an ongoing update of processes and system resources.
  2. Managing Processes: You can manage processes using commands such as kill, nice, and renice.
    • kill sends a signal to a process, typically to terminate it.
    • nice and renice adjust the priority of a process.

docs.title: Service¶
docs.text: • A service in Linux is a special type of background process that is started at boot time or on demand and performs a specific function or provides a particular functionality to other processes or users

docs.title: Key Characteristics:¶
docs.text: • Daemon: Most services are implemented as daemons, background processes that are often started during the boot process.

docs.title: Working with Services:¶
docs.text:
• service [service name] start | stop | restart | status
  • systemctl start | stop | restart | status [service name]
  1. check all available services
    • /usr/lib/systemd/system

docs.title: runlevel in linux¶
docs.text: Linux systems typically define the following runlevels:

docs.title: Runlevel workflow¶
docs.text:
Power on $\to$ BIOS $\to$ /boot $\to$ initprocess $\to$ runlevel

  • runlevel 1 have root power, do not need root password to signin, but need physical signin

docs.title: Check runlevel¶
docs.text:
• vim /etc/inittab: this is the default runlevel
  • systemctl get-default: get current runlevel
    • multi-user.target : runlevel 3
      • ctrl + alt + F3
    • graphical.target : runlevel 5
      • ctrl + alt + F1

docs.title: Change the current runlevel¶
docs.text: • systemctl set-default [Target runlevel].target

docs.title: Set Boot Service and Firewall¶
docs.text:
1. Check Services status
    • systemctl status [Services]
  1. Set to disable
    • systemctl disable [Services]
  1. Check all Services status
    • systemctl list-unit-files

docs.title: Set firewall¶
docs.text:
1. Check firewall status
    • systemctl status firewalld
    • systemctl stop firewalld : stop firewall service for this time

docs.title: Power-off, Reboot and halt¶
docs.text:
1. sync : store data from memory to hard drive
  2. halt : stop services and still power on
  3. poweroff
  4. reboot : equal to shutdown -r now

docs.title: Build NAS Using Laptop
docs.text: • Now you're ready to explore the Hard drive connected your laptop use LAN

docs.title: Building a NAS using a Laptop (Based on Ubuntu)¶
Introduction¶
docs.text:
• A Network Attached Storage (NAS) is a dedicated file storage system that provides local area network (LAN) users with centralized, consolidated disk storage through a standard Ethernet connection.
  • In this tutorial, we will guide you through the steps to turn your old laptop into a NAS using Ubuntu.

docs.title: Prerequisites¶
docs.text:
• An old laptop with Ubuntu installed.
  • An external hard drive or SSD for additional storage.
  • A stable network connection.
  • Basic knowledge of Linux commands.

docs.title: Step 1: Update and Upgrade Your System¶
docs.text:
• First, ensure your system is up to date. Open a terminal and run the following commands:

    sudo apt update
sudo apt upgrade

docs.title: Step 2: Set Up a Static IP Address¶
docs.text:
• To ensure your NAS has a consistent IP address, you need to set up a static IP. Open a terminal and edit the network configuration file:

  • Why? We want your NAS to have a permanent IP (say, 192.168.1.100) so you always know where to find it.

    sudo nano /etc/netplan/01-netcfg.yaml

  • Add the following configuration, replacing the values with your network details (This is just a example, replace address and Gateway with yours):

    network:
  version: 2
  renderer: networkd
  ethernets:
    eth0:
      dhcp4: no
      addresses:
        - 192.168.1.100/24
      gateway4: 192.168.1.1
      nameservers:
        addresses: [8.8.8.8, 8.8.4.4]

  • Apply the changes:

    sudo netplan apply

docs.title: Alternative: Set Up Static IP Address Using GUI¶
docs.text:
• If you prefer to use a graphical user interface (GUI) to set up a static IP address, follow these steps:

    1. Click on the network icon in the system tray.
    2. Select the WiFi network you are connected to and click on "Settings".
    3. Go to the "IPv4" tab.
    4. Change the "Method" to "Manual".
    5. Enter your desired IP address, Netmask, and Gateway.
    6. Add DNS servers if needed.
    7. Save the settings and reconnect to the network.

docs.title: Step 3: Install OpenSSH Server and Test It¶
docs.text:
• To remotely access your NAS, you need to install the OpenSSH server. Open a terminal and run the following command:

    sudo apt install openssh-server

  • Once installed, start and enable the SSH service:

    sudo systemctl start ssh
sudo systemctl enable ssh

  • Test the SSH status on your laptop

    sudo systemctl status ssh

  • Test the SSH connection from another machine on the same network:

    ssh username@192.168.1.100

  • Replace username with your actual username and 192.168.1.100 with the static IP address you set up.

docs.title: Additional Step: Set Up Remote Access with GUI Using Chrome Remote Desktop¶
docs.text: • To access your NAS with a graphical user interface (GUI), you can use Chrome Remote Desktop. Follow these steps:

docs.title: Install Chrome Remote Desktop¶
docs.text:
• Open a terminal and run the following commands to install Chrome Remote Desktop:

    wget https://dl.google.com/linux/direct/chrome-remote-desktop_current_amd64.deb
sudo dpkg -i chrome-remote-desktop_current_amd64.deb
sudo apt-get install -f

docs.title: Install Google Chrome¶
docs.text:
• If you don't have Google Chrome installed, download and install it:

    wget https://dl.google.com/linux/direct/google-chrome-stable_current_amd64.deb
sudo dpkg -i google-chrome-stable_current_amd64.deb
sudo apt-get install -f

docs.title: Install Desktop Environment¶
docs.text:
• Install a desktop environment if you don't have one. For example, you can install Xfce:

    sudo apt install xfce4 xfce4-goodies

docs.title: Configure Chrome Remote Desktop¶
docs.text:
• Link your Google account to Chrome Remote Desktop by visiting remotedesktop.google.com and following the instructions.

  • Set up a new remote access session and choose a name and PIN for your NAS.

docs.title: Step 4: Mount All Drives Permanently and Set Up Easy-to-Remember Mount Paths¶
Identify Your Drives¶
docs.text:
• First, identify the drives you want to mount. Open a terminal and run:

    sudo fdisk -l

  • For GUI, go to disk to check your disk info

docs.title: Create Mount Points¶
docs.text:
• Create directories where you want to mount your drives. For example:

    sudo mkdir -p /mnt/storage1
sudo mkdir -p /mnt/storage2

docs.title: Edit the mount options in disk (GUI)¶
docs.text:
• Uncheck Default option, check Mount at system startup

  • Change the Mount Point to where you just setup

docs.title: Edit the mount option using cmd¶
docs.text:
• To mount the drives permanently, edit the /etc/fstab file:

    sudo nano /etc/fstab

  • Add entries for your drives. Replace UUID with the actual UUID of your drives, which you can find using the blkid command:

    UUID=your-drive-uuid-1 /mnt/storage1 ext4 defaults 0 0
UUID=your-drive-uuid-2 /mnt/storage2 ext4 defaults 0 0

  • Mount the Drives

    • Apply the changes and mount the drives:

      sudo mount -a

  • Verify the Mounts

    • Verify that the drives are mounted correctly:

      df -h

Now your drives are mounted permanently with easy-to-remember names.

docs.title: Install Samba¶
docs.text:
• To share your drives over the network, you need to install Samba. Open a terminal and run the following command:

    sudo apt install samba

docs.title: Configure Samba¶
docs.text:
• Edit the Samba configuration file to add your shared drives:

    sudo nano /etc/samba/smb.conf

  • Add the following configuration at the end of the file, replacing the paths with your actual mount points:

    [share]
comment = share folder
browseable = yes
path = /home/book/Share
create mask = 0755
directory mask = 0755
valid users = book
force user = book
force group = book
public = yes
available = yes
writable = yes

docs.title: Create Samba User¶
docs.text:
• Create a Samba user and set a password:

    sudo smbpasswd -a your_username

docs.title: Restart Samba Service¶
docs.text:
• Restart the Samba service to apply the changes:

    sudo systemctl restart smbd

docs.title: Access Shared Drives¶
docs.text:
• Mac User, use Connect to Server under Go

  • Windows User, right click and select Add a network location

docs.title: Additional Tips: Prevent Laptop from Sleeping When Lid is Closed¶
Open Power Settings:¶
docs.text:
1. Click on the system menu at the top right corner.
  2. Select "Settings" and then go to "Power".

docs.title: Adjust Lid Close Behavior:¶
docs.text:
1. Find the option "When the lid is closed" or similar.
  2. Set it to "Do nothing" or "Turn off screen only". The exact options may vary depending on the version.

docs.title: Save Settings:¶
docs.text: 1. Close the settings window.

docs.title: Method 2: Editing Configuration File¶
docs.text: If the graphical interface does not have the relevant options, you can set it by editing the configuration file:

docs.title: Open Terminal:¶
docs.text: 1. Press Ctrl+Alt+T to open the terminal.

docs.title: Edit logind.conf File:¶
docs.text:
1. Enter the following command to open the configuration file:

    sudo nano /etc/systemd/logind.conf

  2. Find and modify the following two lines: Ensure the following two lines exist and are uncommented (remove the # at the beginning), and modify them to:

    plaintext
HandleLidSwitch=ignore
HandleLidSwitchDocked=ignore

docs.title: Save and Exit:¶
docs.text:
1. Press Ctrl+O to save.
  2. Press Ctrl+X to exit the editor.

docs.title: Restart systemd-logind Service:¶
docs.text:
1. To apply the changes, run the following command:
    sudo systemctl restart systemd-logind

docs.title: Remote Control NAS
docs.text: • You can always goto https://login.tailscale.com/admin/machines to check your Tailscale device list

docs.title: Connect your NAS anywhere using Casa OS and Tailscale¶
docs.text:
• This is a step-by-step guide showing how to add a sleek web interface (CasaOS) to your NAS and make it accessible over the internet using Tailscale.

  • This way, you can manage and access your NAS from anywhere—without messy port forwarding or complicated VPN setups. Let’s dive in!

docs.title: Why CasaOS?¶
docs.text:
• CasaOS is an open-source, simple home-server OS that gives you an attractive, user-friendly dashboard to manage apps, storage, and more.

  • It runs on top of your existing Ubuntu system, so you can keep all the stuff you’ve set up while getting a neat interface for day-to-day tasks.

docs.title: Prerequisites¶
docs.text:
• An Ubuntu-based machine (your old laptop serving as the NAS).

  • Docker installed (CasaOS uses Docker under the hood).

  • Check if Docker is installed:

    docker --version

  • If not installed, follow Docker’s official installation guide or just run:

    sudo apt update
sudo apt install docker.io
sudo systemctl start docker
sudo systemctl enable docker

docs.title: Installing CasaOS¶
docs.text:
• CasaOS provides a handy script to install everything in one go: This script will:

    1. Verify your system requirements.
    2. Install necessary dependencies.
    3. Set up CasaOS and its Docker containers.
    CasaOS provides a handy script to install everything in one go:

  • Once the script finishes, you should see instructions on how to access CasaOS’s web interface. Usually, you can head to:

    http://<Your NAS IP>:80

  • (For example, http://192.168.1.100 if that’s your NAS IP.)

docs.title: First-Time Setup of CasaOS¶
docs.text:
1. Open the web interface in your browser (on the same network, or eventually via Tailscale).

  2. Create an account or log in (depending on the CasaOS version, you might be prompted to set up an admin account).

  3. Explore the dashboard: You’ll see sections for Files, Apps, Settings, etc.

docs.title: Part 2: Expose Your NAS Over the Internet Using Tailscale¶
Why Tailscale?¶
docs.text:
• No port forwarding required: Tailscale creates a secure, peer-to-peer virtual network.

  • Simple setup: A single command to install, then log in with your Google, Microsoft, or GitHub account.

  • Secure: Everything is encrypted; you’re only exposing your NAS to your Tailscale network, not the entire internet.

docs.title: Install Tailscale on Your NAS¶
docs.text:
1. Update your package list:

    sudo apt update

  2. Install Tailscale (for Ubuntu 20.04 and later):

    curl -fsSL https://tailscale.com/install.sh | sh

docs.title: Start Tailscale and Sign In¶
docs.text:
1. Authenticate your NAS to your Tailscale account:

    1. This command opens a browser window (or gives you a URL) asking you to log in to Tailscale.
    2. Once logged in, your NAS will appear in your Tailscale admin console.
    sudo tailscale up

  2. Enable and start Tailscale:

    sudo systemctl enable tailscaled
sudo systemctl start tailscaled

docs.title: Accessing Your NAS via Tailscale¶
docs.text:
1. Install Tailscale into another devices (e.g. iphone), then you should able to see your NAS

  2. When click in, You should see something like 100.xxx.xxx.xxx — that’s your NAS’s Tailscale IP address.

docs.title: Final Wrap-Up¶
docs.text:
• CasaOS gives your NAS a slick, friendly dashboard to manage apps and files.
  • Tailscale creates a secure, hassle-free way to access your NAS from anywhere in the world.

With these two tools combined, your old laptop becomes a powerful, user-friendly, and remotely accessible NAS solution. And you did it all without the headaches of port forwarding or clunky VPNs!

Happy remote NAS-ing! If you ever want to take it further, you could set up other containers in CasaOS, schedule automated backups, or explore Tailscale features like MagicDNS to use a personalized domain. Enjoy your new all-in-one storage system!

docs.title: Build Personal accounting system using firefly iii¶
docs.text: This is a tutorial for setting up a personal accounting system using Firefly III along with its Data Importer. You’ll be using Docker and Docker Compose to run everything in containers for easy setup and management. Let’s go!

docs.title: Check Docker Installation¶
docs.text:
• First things first, make sure Docker is installed on your machine. On Ubuntu/Debian-based systems, you can run:

    docker --version

  • If it says something like Docker version 2x.x.x, you’re good to go. Otherwise, install Docker:

    sudo apt-get update
sudo apt-get install docker.io
sudo systemctl start docker
sudo systemctl enable docker

docs.title: Create a “firefly-iii” Directory & Download the Necessary Files¶
docs.text:
• Make a project folder so it’s easy to keep everything in one place:

    mkdir firefly-iii
cd firefly-iii

  • Now, download the required configuration and environment files:

    # 2.1 Download the Docker-Compose file that includes the Firefly Data Importer
wget -O docker-compose.yml https://raw.githubusercontent.com/firefly-iii/docker/main/docker-compose-importer.yml
